questions.text: A 65 y/o woman with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with fever and malaise. Blood cultures reveal a typical organism causing infective endocarditis. Echocardiography shows a 2 cm vegetation on the mitral valve. Based on the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which of the following is considered a typical organism strongly associated with infective endocarditis (IE)?
questions.explanation:
2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria for infective endocarditis (IE) - Typical and Non-typical Organisms

Typical

Non-Typical

For General cases:

  • Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus lugdunensis
  • Enterococcus faecalis (Option A)
  • All streptococci (except Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus pyogenes)
  • Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, Gemella species
  • HACEK group (e.g., Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella)
 

For cases involving intracardiac prosthetic material, additional typical organisms include:

  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • Corynebacterium striatum, Corynebacterium jeikeium
  • Serratia marcescens, Cutibacterium acnes
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C ruled out)
  • Non-tuberculous mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium chimaera)
  • Candida species

Organisms classified as non-typical are less frequently associated with IE and require three or more positive blood cultures for diagnosis.

 
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option B ruled out)
  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Option D ruled out)
  • Non-faecalis enterococci

questions.text: A 78 y/o male, 3 months post-Transcatheter Aortic Valve Replacement (TAVR), presents with fever and signs of systemic infection. What is the most common causative organism in TAVR-associated infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Duration

Common pathogens

Early PVE (Within the First 2 Months Post-Surgery)

(Often due to direct intraoperative contamination or hematogenous spread.)
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci (Staphylococcus epidermidis, often methicillin-susceptible) (most common)
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Gram-negative bacilli
  • Candida species (Option D ruled out)

Intermediate PVE (2-12 Months Post-Surgery)
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci (S.epidermidis)
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Streptococci
  • Enterococci

Late PVE (After 12 Months Post-Surgery)
  • S.viridans (most common)
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Coagulase-negative staphylococci
  • Enterococci

questions.text: A 72 y/o man presents with fever and night sweats. Blood cultures are repeatedly negative, but PCR testing from a sterile joint aspirate identifies Staphylococcus aureus. Echocardiography reveals mitral regurgitation. Based on the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria, which of the following is a minor criterion for diagnosing infective endocarditis?

options.label: C
options.text: PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen

questions.correct_answer: C. PCR from a sterile body site identifying a typical pathogen
questions.explanation:
The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Minor Criteria Updates

Predisposing Conditions

Expanded to include transcatheter valve procedures, endovascular leads of cardiac implantable devices, and a history of IE.

Vascular Phenomenon

Includes splenic and cerebral abscesses.

Immunological Phenomena

Clarifies immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, with a practical definition involving unexplained acute kidney injury, hematuria, proteinuria, or a renal biopsy showing immune complex disease.

Microbiological Evidence

PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing of typical pathogens from sterile sites other than cardiac tissue is now a minor criterion. (Option C)

Imaging

Abnormal metabolic activity detected by [18F]FDG PET/CT within three months of prosthetic valve or device implantation is included.

Physical Exam

A new regurgitant murmur on auscultation is considered a minor criterion when echocardiography is unavailable.

questions.text: A 70 y/o man with a prosthetic aortic valve has a fever, positive blood cultures for Enterococcus faecalis, valve vegetation, and regurgitation on ECHO. Cardiac Computed Tomography shows a valve abscess. Which finding is a new major criterion for infective endocarditis in the 2023 Duke-ISCVID criteria?

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiac computed tomography (CCT) showing valvular abscess

options.label: C
options.text: Positive blood cultures with Enterococcus faecalis

options.label: D
options.text: Development of a new valve regurgitation

questions.correct_answer: A. Cardiac computed tomography (CCT) showing valvular abscess
questions.explanation:
The 2023 Duke-International Society for Cardiovascular Infectious Diseases (ISCVID) Criteria for Infective Endocarditis - Major Criteria Updates

Microbiological Criteria
  • Expanded "Typical" Pathogens:
    • The list now includes Staphylococcus lugdunensis, Enterococcus faecalis, and other streptococci, excluding S. pneumoniae and S. pyogenes.
    • Additionally, Granulicatella, Abiotrophia, and Gemella species are now recognised as typical IE pathogens.
  • Prosthetic Material-Associated Pathogens:
    • In intracardiac prosthetic devices, certain bacteria like coagulase-negative staphylococci and Corynebacterium species, as well as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, are considered typical.
  • Simplified Blood Culture Protocol:
    • Timing and separate venipuncture rules have been removed, though separate draws are still ideal.
  • Fastidious Pathogens:
    • New criteria account for hard-to-culture organisms like Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella, and Tropheryma whipplei, diagnosed via PCR or specific serology.

Imaging Criteria
  • Cardiac CT (CCT):
    • Findings like valvular vegetation, perforation, aneurysm, intracardiac fistula or abscesses on CCT are now considered major criteria. (Option A)
  • [18F]FDG PET/CT:
    • Abnormal metabolic activity on [18F]FDG PET/CT, especially around prosthetic valves or intracardiac devices, is recognised as a major diagnostic criterion.

Surgical Evidence
  • Intraoperative Findings:
    • Direct visual evidence of IE during surgery, such as vegetations or abscesses, qualifies as a major criterion in cases without other definitive findings.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents to the dental clinic for a tooth extraction. He has a prosthetic heart valve placed two years ago and reports a penicillin allergy. He is otherwise healthy. Which of the following prophylactic antibiotic regimens should be administered to this patient before his dental procedure to prevent infective endocarditis?

options.label: A
options.text: Amoxicillin 2g orally 1 hour before the procedure

options.label: B
options.text: Ampicillin 2g IV or IM within 1 hour before the procedure

options.label: C
options.text: Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure

options.label: D
options.text: Cefazolin 1g IV or IM 30 minutes before the procedure

questions.correct_answer: C. Clarithromycin 500 mg orally 1 hour before the procedure
questions.explanation:
High-risk cardiac Lesions for endocarditis prophylaxis before dental procedures

Prophylactic Antibiotic Regimens for endocarditis in adults with high-risk cardiac lesions
  • Prosthetic heart valves or material
  • Left ventricular assist devices or implantable cardiac defibrillator.
  • Prior endocarditis.
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, including palliative shunts or conduits.
  • Completely repaired congenital heart defects during the 6 months after repair.
  • Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects adjacent to the prosthetic material.
  • Surgical or transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation.

Standard oral regimen

(Option A ruled out)

Amoxicillin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure

Inability to take oral medication

(Option B ruled out)

Ampicillin: 2g IV or IM within 1hr before procedure

Penicillin allergy

  1. Clarithromycin or Azithromycin: 500 mg PO 1hr before procedure.
  2. Cephalexin: 2g oral 1hr before procedure.
  3. Doxycycline: 100 mg oral 1hr before procedure.

Penicillin allergy, inability to take oral medication (Option D ruled out)

Cefazolin or Ceftriaxone: 1g IV or IM 30 mins before the procedure.

questions.text: A 55 y/o man with a history of prosthetic valve presents with fever, chills, and fatigue. Blood cultures reveal methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The patient has a prosthetic valve and shows evidence of vegetation on echocardiography. What is the appropriate antibiotic regimen for managing this patient’s infection?
questions.explanation:
Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
  • NVE: Vancomycin or Daptomycin for 6 weeks. (Option B ruled out)
  • PVE: Vancomycin + Rifampin(both for 6-8 weeks)+ Gentamicin(for 2 weeks)

Methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA)
  • PVE: Nafcillin + Rifampin (both for 6-8 weeks)

+ Gentamicin(for 2 weeks) (Option C ruled out)

Enterococcal Endocarditis
  • Ampicillin + Gentamicin both for 4-6 weeks (Option D ruled out)

Streptococcal Endocarditis
  • Ceftriaxone/Penicillin + Gentamicin.

Q fever (Coxiella burnetii)
  • Doxycycline + Hydroxychloroquine.

Bartonella Endocarditis
  • Doxycycline + Gentamicin.

Fungal Endocarditis (Candida species)
  • IV Amphotericin B + Flucytosine.
    • If PVE, early surgery is recommended due to rapid progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is a minor criterion under the Modified Duke’s Criteria for infective endocarditis?

options.label: B
options.text: Two positive blood cultures with a typical organism

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of a prosthetic valve
questions.explanation:
Modified Duke’s Criteria - Minor criteria

Predisposing heart condition

Any pre-existing valvular or cardiac abnormality, such as valvular disease, congenital heart defects, or prosthetic valves. (Option C)

Intravenous drug use

Recognised as a significant risk factor for IE.

Fever ≥ 38°C

Commonly seen in patients with IE.

Vascular phenomena

Such as embolic events (stroke, septic pulmonary infarcts), mycotic aneurysms, intracranial haemorrhages and Janeway lesions.

Immunological phenomena

Rheumatoid factor, Osler’s nodes, Roth's spots or glomerulonephritis.

Positive blood culture not meeting major criteria

Isolation of organisms typical of IE in a single culture or other non-major findings.

Suggestive echocardiography

Abnormal findings that raise suspicion but do not meet the criteria for a major criterion. (D529)

questions.text: A 60 y/o man with a mechanical aortic valve presents with 2 weeks of fever, fatigue, and shortness of breath. He has a history of a dental procedure done 3 weeks back. Blood cultures are negative. FDG-PET/CT shows abnormal uptake around the valve. Which major criterion from the Modified Duke’s Criteria does this patient meet?

options.label: A
options.text: Negative blood culture for a typical organism

options.label: B
options.text: Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT

questions.correct_answer: B. Evidence of endocardial involvement by FDG-PET/CT
questions.explanation:
Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least one hour apart.
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

questions.text: A 60- y/o woman with a history of RHD presents to the OPD with complaints of persistent fatigue, fever, and visual disturbances. O/E multiple linear red to brownish streaks under her fingernails and a pale-centred retinal haemorrhage were observed. Blood cultures reveal the presence of Staphylococcus aureus . Which peripheral lesions associated with the patient’s condition are described by the patient's symptoms?
questions.correct_answer: B. Roth spots and splinter haemorrhages
questions.explanation:
Janeway lesions:

Painless, erythematous macules on palms and soles. Related to septic microembolization,

(Option A ruled out)

Osler’s nodes:

Small painful pea-shaped nodules located at the tips of fingers and toes (Immune complex mediated). (Option A ruled out)

 

Subungual haemorrhages/Splinter haemorrhages:

More common in acute S. aureus IE. Haemorrhages below nails- multiple linear lesions, initially red then turning brown or black.

Roth spots:

Pale-centred retinal haemorrhages that are seen in the fundus examination

questions.text: In the context of infective endocarditis, what role do MSCRAMMs play in the disease process?

options.label: A
options.text: They enhance the immune response against pathogens during bacteremia.

options.label: B
options.text: They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.

options.label: C
options.text: They are responsible for the formation of emboli that lead to tissue infarction.

options.label: D
options.text: They promote the breakdown of vegetation formed in the heart.

questions.correct_answer: B. They facilitate bacterial adherence to nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) or injured endothelium.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with fever, malaise, and a new heart murmur. He recently underwent a urinary catheterisation for urinary retention. Blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci. What is the most likely causative organism of his infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Portals of entry

Oral cavity:

The entry point for viridans streptococci.

Skin:

Common entry point for staphylococci and S.epidermidis.

Upper respiratory tract:

Source for HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, Kingella). (Option D ruled out)

Gastrointestinal tract:

Streptococcus gallolyticus (formerly S. bovis) is associated with colonic polyps and tumours. (Option B ruled out)

Genitourinary tract and GI tract procedures ( catheterization, colonoscopy):

Source for enterococci.

Nosocomial (hospital-acquired) sources:

S. aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), and enterococci are often linked to healthcare-associated infective endocarditis. (Option A ruled out)

Prosthetic valve infections (PVE):

Intraoperative contamination or postoperative infection, especially with S. aureus, CoNS, and gram-negative bacilli.

Intravenous drug use:

Primary portal for S. aureus infections, especially in tricuspid valve involvement. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A 68 y/o male with a prosthetic valve presents with fever, night sweats, and fatigue 6 months post-surgery. Blood cultures are negative, and he was exposed to a contaminated heater-cooler device during valve replacement. Which organism is most likely responsible for his prosthetic valve endocarditis?

A 30 y/o female with a history of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) presents with fever, fatigue, and a new-onset systolic murmur. Her recent echocardiogram shows vegetation along the inner lining of her aorta. She is an intravenous drug user and has been experiencing unexplained weight loss over the past month. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on her symptoms and history?

A 72 y/o female with a history of mitral valve prolapse presents with a low-grade fever, night sweats, and fatigue persisting for over a month. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and petechiae on her extremities. Blood cultures are sent. What is the leading organism associated with this patient's probable condition?
questions.explanation:
Acute Bacterial Endocarditis

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis (SBE)
  • Aggressive course compared to subacute endocarditis.
  • Causative organisms: S. aureus (Most common cause) (including MRSA), S. pneumoniae, L. monocytogenes, Haemophilus species, streptococci (groups A, B, G).
  • Risk factors: Comorbid conditions like malignancy, diabetes mellitus, IV drug use, or alcoholism.
  • Presentation:
    • Fever, fatigue, and malaise within <2 weeks of infection.
    • Changing heart murmur, potential congestive heart failure.
    • Possible signs: Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic macules on palms/soles), petechiae, Roth’s spots, splinter haemorrhages, splenomegaly (rare).
  • Slow progression compared to Acute endocarditis
  • Causative organism: Streptococcus viridans (Most common cause)
  • Presentation:
    • Gradual onset over weeks to months (>2 weeks) but can be life-threatening if untreated.
    • Symptoms: unexplained fever, chills, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, joint/muscle aches, chest/back pain, and skin rashes.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Periodontal disease, IV drug use, prolonged IV medication.
    • Congenital heart defects, prior endocarditis, valve surgery, or pacemaker implants.
    • More common in men, especially over age 60.
  • Treatment:
    • High-dose IV antibiotics for 2-6 weeks.
    • Surgery may be needed for abscess drainage or valve repair/replacement.

questions.text: Which of the following lists the valves in order of frequency of involvement in infective endocarditis, from most to least commonly affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic valve > Mitral valve > Pulmonic valve > Tricuspid valve

options.label: C
options.text: Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Pulmonic valve

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonic valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Mitral valve

questions.correct_answer: A. Mitral valve > Aortic valve > Tricuspid valve > Pulmonic valve

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding right-sided infective endocarditis (IE)?

options.label: A
options.text: Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided infective endocarditis.

options.label: B
options.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common pathogen in right-sided infective endocarditis

options.label: C
options.text: Injecting particles are more likely to reach the right-sided valves compared to the left-sided valves

options.label: D
options.text: Right-sided infective endocarditis has a better long-term prognosis compared to left-sided infective endocarditis

questions.correct_answer: A. Right-sided infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with enterococci than left-sided infective endocarditis.
questions.explanation:
Right-Sided IDU-Associated IE

Left-Sided IDU-Associated IE
  • Valve Involvement: Predominantly affects the tricuspid valve.
  • Causative Pathogen: Staphylococcus aureus (Especially MRSA) is responsible for 85% of cases , primarily due to poor injection hygiene. (Option B ruled out)
  • Pathophysiology: Injected particles damage right-sided valves. Bacteremia from skin bacteria (like S. aureus) easily colonizes these valves.
  • Surgical Intervention: Surgery is rare and tricuspid valve insufficiency is generally well tolerated.
  • Prognosis: Right-sided IE has a better long-term prognosis. (Option D ruled out)
  • Valve Involvement: Affects the aortic or mitral valves, occurring in about 20-30% of IDU-related IE cases.
  • Causative Pathogen: S. aureus causes 46% of cases, but alpha-hemolytic streptococci and enterococci are more common than in right-sided IE. (Option A)
  • Pathophysiology: Left-sided IE often occurs in individuals with underlying valve disease or degenerative changes, which are more common in older patients. Injected particles are less likely to reach the left-sided valves because they often get trapped in the lungs. (Option C ruled out)
  • Surgical Intervention: Surgery is much more common due to the more severe nature of left-sided lesions (e.g., abscess formation, severe heart failure).
  • Prognosis: Left-sided IE has a worse prognosis

questions.text: A 72 y/o woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath after a stressful argument. She is post-menopausal with no history of heart disease. O/E, she is slightly tachycardic with normal blood pressure. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular ballooning during systole, and cardiac enzymes are minimally elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Gebrochenes-Herz syndrome)

About
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken-heart syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a non-ischemic condition primarily affecting post-menopausal women.
  • It features temporary left ventricular dysfunction that resembles a heart attack but with minimal cardiac enzyme release and no significant obstructive coronary artery disease.
  • The name "Takotsubo" is derived from Japanese, meaning octopus trap, reflecting the ballooning shape of the left ventricle during contraction.

Pathophysiology
  • Catecholamine Hypothesis: Elevated catecholamines (norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) indicate stress-induced sympathetic overdrive, leading to microvascular spasms and myocardial injury.
  • Microvascular Dysfunction: Impaired function is suggested by abnormalities in coronary flow reserve and microvascular resistance.
  • Inflammation: Imaging may show myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis, with conditions like myocarditis and autoimmune diseases potentially triggering TC.
  • Estrogen Deficiency: Exaggerated vasoconstriction and increased sympathetic activity in post-menopausal women contribute to TC.

Clinical features
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy often mimics acute coronary syndrome.(MI)
  • Common Triggers:
    • Emotional Stress: Events like the unexpected death of a loved one, domestic abuse, or financial loss.
    • Physical Stress: Serious medical diagnoses or natural disasters.
  • Symptoms: Chest pain, dyspnea, and syncope. Some patients may have signs of heart failure, such as tachyarrhythmias or bradyarrhythmias.
  • A late-peaking systolic murmur may be present due to LVOTO (Left Ventricular Outflow Tract Obstruction).
  • About 10% of patients may develop cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common echocardiographic finding associated with rheumatic carditis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Findings

Incidence/Notes

Mitral Valve Involvement

Mitral regurgitation

94% in first episodes, 84% in recurrences

Ventricular dilatation

54% in first episodes, 74% in recurrences

Restricted leaflet mobility

37% of recurrent cases

Valvular Abnormalities

Valvular thickening

Thickened mitral valve leaflets

Focal valvular nodules

25%, usually resolved over time

Other Cardiac Changes

Left ventricular function

Normal despite mitral regurgitation

Congestive heart failure (CHF)

17% of first episodes, 40% of recurrences

Follow-Up

Valvular regurgitation outcomes

69% unchanged, 22% decreased, 9% disappeared

Left ventricular dimensions

Decrease over time

questions.text: A 12 y/o girl presents with a recent onset of involuntary, jerky movements in her hands and face, worsening with stress or purposeful tasks. Her mother recalls multiple untreated sore throats months ago. O/E, she has irregular, rapid, non-rhythmic hand movements, difficulty with facial control, and trouble sustaining muscle contraction. Her motor function is otherwise normal. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.explanation:
Category

Medications

Purpose

Initial Antibiotic Prophylaxis

Benzathine penicillin G

Prevent the recurrence of rheumatic fever

Additional Treatment

Neuroleptics: Pimozide, haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine (Option B ruled out)

Control chorea symptoms

Anticonvulsants: Valproate, carbamazepine (Option D ruled out)

Off-label use for symptom management

Immunomodulatory Therapy

Corticosteroids, Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG), Plasma exchange (Option C ruled out)

For severe/persistent symptoms

Monitoring

Gradual tapering after 1 month of symptom-free

Reduce side effects

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with h/o exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and episodes of syncope. She recalls experiencing multiple episodes of sore throat as a child, followed by joint pains, for which she received no definitive treatment. On auscultation, there is a diastolic murmur at the apex and a loud S1. She has heart rate of 75-80 bpm. An echocardiogram reveals significant mitral stenosis with left atrial enlargement. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: ACE Inhibitors and rate control drugs

questions.explanation:
Condition

Medical Management

Interventional/Surgical Options

Mitral Stenosis
  • Anticoagulation to prevent embolism.
  • Rate control (e.g., digoxin, beta-blockers, calcium antagonists) in AF.(Option C ruled out)
  • Diuretics for pulmonary congestion.
  • Balloon valvuloplasty.
  • Mitral valvotomy.
  • Mitral valve replacement.

Mitral Regurgitation
  • Diuretics and vasodilators for symptom relief.
  • Digoxin and anticoagulants in AF.
  • ACE inhibitors/ARBs for hypertension. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mitral valve repair (preferred). (Option B ruled out)
  • Mitral valve replacement (if repair is not feasible).

Aortic Stenosis

Not applicable

Aortic valve replacement (for severe stenosis with symptoms like angina, syncope, or heart failure).

Aortic Regurgitation

Not applicable

Aortic valve replacement (indicated for symptomatic cases, sometimes combined with aortic root replacement or coronary bypass).

Therapy

Details

Medical Therapy

Medications to improve cardiac function, reduce fluid overload, and control blood pressure. Eg. Diuretics, ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Device Therapy

ICD (Implantable cardiac defibrillators): For preventing sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias.

CRT (Cardiac resynchronisation therapy): For improving heart function in heart failure with conduction abnormalities (e.g., left bundle branch block).

Prevention Strategy

Details

Long-Term Antibiotic Prophylaxis

Prevents recurrent attacks of rheumatic fever.

Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Procedures

May be necessary before dental or surgical procedures to reduce the risk of infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and occasional palpitations. She denies chest pain or fainting. O/E, she has an irregular pulse, a loud S1, an opening snap, and a low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex. She recalls a childhood illness with fever and joint pain requiring hospitalization. No signs of recent infection are present. Which of the following investigations is NOT primarily used in diagnosing her condition?
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Diagnosis of RHD

Blood Tests

Leukocytosis, ESR, CRP
  • Indicators of systemic illness.
  • Raised ESR and CRP are common inflammatory markers.

Throat Swab Culture
  • Used to identify group A β-haemolytic streptococci.
  • Cultures may also be taken from family members and contacts to confirm the source of infection.

Antistreptolysin O (ASO) titres
  • Elevated ASO levels (> 200 U in adults, > 300 U in children) or rising titres support the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever.
  • Normal ASO titres do not rule out the disease.

Investigations

Electrocardiogram (ECG) (Option B ruled out)
  • Shows first-degree, and rarely, second-degree atrioventricular block.
  • Pericarditis features.
  • T-wave inversion.
  • QRS voltage reduction.

Chest X-ray (Option D ruled out)
  • Identifies cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion.

Echocardiography

(Option A ruled out)
  • Reveals cardiac dilatation.
  • Detects valve abnormalities: Commonly mitral regurgitation with mitral annulus dilatation and anterior mitral leaflet prolapse.
  • Shows aortic regurgitation.
  • Identifies pericardial effusion.

Excluding Differentials

Other Valvular Diseases

Infective endocarditis

  • Blood cultures: Identify pathogens.
  • Echocardiography: Detects vegetation on valves.

Congenital heart defects

Doppler Echocardiography: Identifies defects and abnormal blood flow patterns.

Other Cardiac Conditions

Cardiomyopathies

Echocardiography/Cardiac MRI: Show structural/functional myocardial abnormalities to differentiate from RHD.

Pericardial diseases

Echocardiography: Detects pericardial effusion (pericarditis), and thickened pericardium (constrictive pericarditis).

Non-Cardiac Conditions

Pulmonary conditions

Investigations: Chest X-ray, ECG, CT pulmonary angiogram (pulmonary embolism).

Systemic illnesses

Blood tests: Haemoglobin (anaemia), thyroid function, and kidney function to exclude other causes of cardiovascular symptoms.

questions.text: Based on the 2015 Modified Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Fever, which of the following is NOT part of the major criteria for a low-risk population?
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Low-Risk Population

High-Risk Population

Major Criteria
  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical) (Option A ruled out)
  • Polyarthritis (Option B ruled out)
  • Chorea (Option C ruled out)
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Carditis (clinical or subclinical)
  • Monoarthritis or Polyarthritis
  • Chorea
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Subcutaneous nodules
  • Polyarthralgia (Option D)

Minor Criteria
  • Polyarthralgia (Option D)
  • Hyperpyrexia (≥ 38.5ºC)
  • ESR ≥ 60 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl
  • Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion)
  • Monoarthralgia
  • Hyperpyrexia (≥ 38.0ºC)
  • ESR ≥ 30 mm/h and/or CRP ≥ 3.0 mg/dl
  • Prolonged PR interval (if no there is no carditis in major criterion)

questions.text: Which statements describe the relationship between Sydenham's chorea and acute rheumatic fever?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an early manifestation of rheumatic fever

options.label: B
options.text: It occurs in all patients with rheumatic fever

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with emotional lability

options.label: D
options.text: It has no connection to previous infections

questions.correct_answer: C. It is associated with emotional lability

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a new onset heart murmur. On auscultation, a soft mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Echocardiography reveals mitral valve inflammation. Which of the following murmurs is most likely present in this patient?
Which of the following clinical features is most commonly associated with Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) in the Indian population?
questions.explanation:
The course of Acute Rheumatic Fever

Latent Period

Common Early Features

Late Features
  • After upper respiratory tract infection/ pharyngitis with GABHS, ARF symptoms typically develop after a latent period of 3 weeks (range: 1–5 weeks).
  • A sore throat can occur.
  • Chorea and indolent carditis can manifest up to 6 months later following a prolonged latent period.
  • Polyarthritis: Seen in 60-75% of ARF cases, often affecting large joints (knees, ankles, elbows). Migratory inflammation is a key feature.
  • Carditis: Occurs in 50-75% of cases, frequently leading to mitral valve damage (regurgitation initially). Aortic valve involvement is also common..
  • Valvular damage can progress from regurgitation to stenosis over time, leading to heart failure in the long term.
  • Recurrent ARF episodes increase the risk of chronic heart valve disease (rheumatic heart disease).
  • Chorea: Varies by population, from less than 2% to 30%. Predominantly affects females and often coexists with carditis.
  • Skin Manifestations: Erythema marginatum (rare, less than 5% of cases) and subcutaneous nodules (also less than 5%). (Options B and C ruled out)

questions.text: A 10 y/o boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat. Examination reveals a heart murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. Laboratory tests show elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct invasion of heart valves by Streptococcus bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune destruction of heart valves due to viral infection

options.label: D
options.text: Genetic mutations in heart muscle proteins

questions.correct_answer: B. Immune response triggered by molecular mimicry between bacterial antigens and heart tissue

questions.text: A 16 y/o boy with a history of acute rheumatic fever (ARF) without carditis presents for follow-up. He has been on benzathine penicillin G for four years. Based on the AHA guidelines, what is the recommended duration for continuing secondary prophylaxis in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 25

options.label: D
options.text: Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21

questions.correct_answer: D. Continue prophylaxis until the age of 21
questions.explanation:
Secondary Prevention in Acute Rheumatic Fever

Preferred Antibiotic

Benzathine penicillin G is recommended as the first choice. Dosage is:

  • 1.2 million units for individuals >27 kg.
  • 600,000 units for individuals ≤27 kg.

Typically administered every 4 weeks, may increase to every 2–3 weeks for adherence issues.

Alternative Antibiotics

Oral Erythromycin (250 mg twice daily) is recommended for patients allergic to penicillin.

Oral penicillin V (250 mg twice daily) can be used but is less effective.

Duration of Prophylaxis

Determined by the presence and severity of carditis, age, and time since the last ARF episode

No Carditis

(Option B)

5 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Carditis without Valvular Disease

10 years or until 21 years of age, whichever is longer.

Persistent Valvular Disease

10 years or until 40 years of age, whichever is longer.

Lifelong prophylaxis may be needed in severe cases.

questions.text: An interventional cardiologist is planning to implant an ICD in several patients. Which of the following patients is NOT an indication for ICD implantation according to the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Rhythm Society guidelines?

A 55 y/o male presents to the ED with severe chest pain radiating to his left arm. His ECG is given below. Based on this information, which of the following changes is most likely present in this ECG?

A 35 y/o male presents to the ED after experiencing a brief episode of syncope. He reports occasional palpitations and dizziness. His family history is significant for sudden cardiac deaths at a young age. An ECG of leads V1-V3 is given below. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient, given the findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe a beta-blocker and advise lifestyle modifications

options.label: B
options.text: Perform a drug challenge test with procainamide

options.label: C
options.text: Refer for genetic testing for SCN5A mutations

questions.explanation:
Brugada Syndrome

About

A rare, inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, characterised by right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) on ECG.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms range from asymptomatic to sudden cardiac death, often during sleep.
  • Syncope in 80% of patients with ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
  • Other symptoms: palpitations, dizziness, and fever history may trigger symptoms.

ECG findings
  • Type I: Coved ST elevations >2 mm with inverted T wave.
  • Type II: Saddleback-shaped ST elevation >2 mm.
  • Type III: Saddleback-shaped ST elevations <2 mm.
  • Patients with a normal ECG and high-risk factors may need a drug challenge test to reveal ST elevations in leads V1 to V3. 

Drug challenge test
  • Drugs used in the challenge test:
    • Class IA antiarrhythmics (procainamide, ajmaline).
    • IC antiarrhythmics (flecainide, propafenone).
  • Brugada ECG findings can also emerge from cocaine use or tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities like hyperkalemia and hypercalcemia can reveal ST elevations in the right precordial leads.
  • A normal drug challenge test in pediatric patients may need to be repeated after puberty due to hormonal influences.
  • The "full stomach test" can also help expose ST elevations by increasing vagal tone.
  • Additional diagnostic options include genetic testing for SCN5A mutations and invasive electrophysiology.

Treatment
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients.

questions.text: A 68 y/o postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with chest pain and dyspnea after a recent stressful event. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation and cardiac biomarkers are mildly elevated. After a thorough evaluation, she is diagnosed with a condition resembling acute coronary syndrome. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin.

questions.correct_answer: D. Perform immediate coronary angiography and start aspirin.
questions.explanation:
Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

Investigations
  • ECG Changes: Similar to pericarditis stages, with ST-segment elevation, T-wave inversions, and eventual normalization.
  • Cardiac Biomarkers: Mild elevation of troponins (median initial troponin: 7.7 times normal) and elevated BNP or N-terminal pro-BNP levels.
  • Echocardiography: Systolic apical ballooning of LV with mid-apical depression.
  • Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance (CMR): Helps diagnose stress cardiomyopathy, showing myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis.

Treatment
  • Risk Factors for Adverse Outcomes: Physical triggers, neurologic/psychiatric conditions, high initial troponin, low ejection fraction, male gender.
  • Initial Treatment: Aspirin, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, lipid-lowering agents, and coronary angiography.
  • Stable Patients:
    • Cardioselective beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors for 3-6 months.
    • Serial imaging to monitor wall motion and ejection fraction.
  • Anticoagulation: Reserved for patients with ventricular thrombus (5% occurrence). (Option A ruled out)
  • Unstable Patients: Inotropes for cardiogenic shock without left ventricular outflow obstruction. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mechanical support (intra-aortic balloon pump or left ventricular assist devices) may be needed.
  • If Outflow Obstruction Present: Avoid inotropes; phenylephrine is the preferred pressor, often combined with beta-blockers.

Echocardiogram showing "apical ballooning" pattern

Left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning akinesis with basal hyperkinesis in a characteristic Takotsubo ventricle.
